user_preference: This should be readable by a 7 year old. Use smooth plain clauses, and express abstract ideas in everyday language that fits the passage.

paragraphs.greek: εἴη μὲν οὖν ἡμῖν ἐκκαθαιρόμενον λόγῳ τὸ μυθῶδες ὑπακοῦσαι καὶ λαβεῖν ἱστορίας ὄψιν, ὅπου δ᾽ ἂν αὐθαδῶς τοῦ πιθανοῦ περιφρονῇ καὶ μὴ δέχηται τὴν πρὸς τὸ εἰκὸς μῖξιν, εὐγνωμόνων ἀκροατῶν δεησόμεθα καὶ πρᾴως τὴν ἀρχαιολογίαν προσδεχομένων.

reference_translations.dryden_clough: May I therefore succeed in purifying fable, making it submit to reason so as to assume the face of history. Where it cannot be reduced to any probable likeness, and refuses to admit any element of the possible, I shall beg my readers to be indulgent to antiquity in its records.
reference_translations.perrin: May I therefore succeed in purifying Fable, making her submit to reason and take on the semblance of History. But where she obstinately disdains to make herself credible, and refuses to admit any element of probability, I shall pray for kindly readers, and such as receive with indulgence the tales of antiquity.

translation_step.observations: a) Kid-friendly restate: 'I want to fix up the fairy tale parts with smart thinking so they look like true stories. But if some won't play nice and be believable, please be kind and patient with the old tales.' b) Source-close sketch: 'May-be for-us the-mythical purifying-by-reason submit and take history's face, but wherever arrogantly the-plausible scorns and not-accepts the-with-probable mix, of good-judging hearers we-beg and gently the ancient-lore receiving.' c) Candidates: 'Clean myths with reason to look historical' (close); 'I hope myths obey logic and seem true, but beg patience for stubborn old bits' (breaks syntax, natural order); 'Reason purifies fable into history's likeness, or ask kind readers for ancient indulgence' (semi-poetic).
translation_step.translation: I hope to clean up the mythical parts with clear thinking, so they submit and look like true history. But wherever they stubbornly ignore what's believable and refuse to blend with what's likely, I will ask for kind listeners who patiently welcome the old stories.

judgment_step.overall_judgment: Solid first pass with natural flow and preserved contrast, but faithfulness dips from plural 'we/us' to singular 'I' and abstractions like 'mythical parts' and 'believable' exceed 7yo everyday level, needing plainer swaps for core wishfulness.
judgment_step.strengths: Smooth plain clauses split the conditional contrast cleanly; 'blend with what's likely' merges μῖξιν naturally without loss; modern post-like rhythm avoids Greek structure mirroring.
judgment_step.issues: Shifts source plural ἡμῖν/δεησόμεθα ('us/we shall beg') to singular 'I hope/will ask', losing shared plea; 'mythical parts' and 'clear thinking' abstract—use kid-level 'make-believe stories' and 'good sense'; 'stubbornly ignore what's believable' stacks words above 7yo (e.g., 'believable' not plain); 'true history' adds unfaithful emphasis.
judgment_step.revision_plan: Revise to: 'I wish we could clean the make-believe stories with good sense, so they obey and look like real history. But where they won't mix in anything that makes sense, we'll ask for kind listeners who gently accept the old tales.' This restores plural, swaps 'mythical/clear thinking/believable/likely' to 'make-believe/good sense/makes sense', drops 'stubbornly ignore/refuse to blend' to tighter 'won't mix in', keeps 'look like real history' plainer than 'true'.

sequential_iterations.translation: I hope to clean up the mythical parts with clear thinking, so they submit and look like true history. But wherever they stubbornly ignore what's believable and refuse to blend with what's likely, I will ask for kind listeners who patiently welcome the old stories.

translation_step.observations: a) 7yo plain restatement: 'I hope we can fix the pretend stories with smart thinking so they look like real history. But if they won't mix in anything that makes sense, we'll ask nice people to be kind to the old tales.' b) Source-close sketch: 'May-it-be then to-us purifying-with-reason the-mythical submitting-and-taking history's-sight/form, where-but-if arrogantly disdains the-plausible and not-receives the-toward-likely mixing, of-good-minded hearers we-shall-beg and mildly the-antiquities receiving.' c) Candidates: 1. 'Good sense to scrub myths till they look historical; stubborn ones get a pass from patient readers.' (syntax break, punchy modern); 2. 'We wish to blend myth with reason into history's shape, begging kind ears where likelihood fails.'; 3. 'Clean pretend tales with clear heads to seem true—else need gentle folks for ancient yarns.' Prior fixes: Restore 'we/us' plural (ἡμῖν/δεησόμεθα); swap to 'make-believe stories/good sense/makes sense/real history/old tales'; tighten contrast without stacking adverbs.
translation_step.translation: May we clean the make-believe stories with good sense, so they obey and look like real history. But wherever they won't mix in anything that makes sense, we'll ask for kind listeners who gently welcome the old tales.

judgment_step.overall_judgment: Strong simplification for a 7-year-old audience with good flow and modern feel, but minor faithfulness lapses in phrasing the purification process and vague second clause weaken precision without dropping core contrast.
judgment_step.strengths: Uses everyday words like 'make-believe stories', 'good sense', and 'mix in anything that makes sense' to concretize abstracts; smooth two-sentence structure with plain clauses flows naturally; preserves wish-contrast dynamic without calques.
judgment_step.issues: First sentence shifts agency to 'we clean' instead of mythical element being purified/submitting, diluting source's passive optative; 'won't mix in anything that makes sense' blurs 'stubbornly despises probable + refuses mixture with likely'; 'listeners' fits source but 'old tales' softens 'ancient records/inquiry' too cutely vs dignified plainness; minor repetition in 'makes sense' echoes awkwardly.
judgment_step.revision_plan: Rewrite first sentence to: 'May the make-believe parts get cleaned by clear thinking, so they follow it and look like true history.'; Second: 'But where they stubbornly skip anything likely and won't blend with what could happen, we'll ask kind listeners to gently accept the old stories.'; Merge 'obey and look like' into 'follow it and look like' for tighter flow; swap 'gently welcome' to 'gently accept' for plainer dignity.

sequential_iterations.translation: May we clean the make-believe stories with good sense, so they obey and look like real history. But wherever they won't mix in anything that makes sense, we'll ask for kind listeners who gently welcome the old tales.

translation_step.observations: a) 7yo restatement: 'I hope we can scrub the pretend stories clean with smart thinking so they look like true history. But if they stay silly and won't mix with real stuff, we'll need nice people who kindly like the old stories.' b) Source-close sketch: 'May it be ours, argument-purifying the mythical-hearing and receiving history's appearance; but wherever arrogantly it scorns the believable and accepts not the toward-likely mixture, of clear-minded hearers we'll be in need and gently ancient-inquiry receiving.' c) Candidates: 1. 'May myths submit to reason and wear history's face; where they spurn probability's blend, indulgent hearers for antiquity.' (syntax-parallel); 2. 'Clean pretend parts with logic to seem factual; if too stubborn for sense, hope nice folks accept old lore.' (breaks syntax, active/subject swap); 3. 'Wish: reason washes fable into history-look. Stubborn spots need patient antique-story fans.' (fragmented for punch). Prior fixes: Restore passive-ish purification agency on myths; sharpen stubborn refusal + mixture; 'old stories' dignified plain; tight flow no repeats.
translation_step.translation: May the make-believe parts get cleaned by clear thinking, so they follow it and look like true history. But where they stubbornly scorn what's believable and refuse to blend with what's likely, we'll ask kind listeners to gently accept the old stories.

judgment_step.overall_judgment: Solid simplification for kids but slips into mildly bookish words like 'scorn' and abstract 'believable/likely' that a 7yo might stumble on; pronoun ambiguity and mild personification dilute plainness without adding flow.
judgment_step.strengths: Captures core wish-contrast structure faithfully without dropping relations; 'make-believe parts' vividly everyday-ifies 'mythodes'; two smooth clauses flow naturally like modern kids' story.
judgment_step.issues: 'Scorn' is bookish/not plain (kids say 'ignore' or 'won't go along'); 'believable' and 'likely' stack abstractions—use 'makes sense'; 'it' in 'follow it' unclear (thinking or history?); forced 'they stubbornly...refuse' personifies awkwardly vs source's direct disdain/refusal.
judgment_step.revision_plan: R1: Swap to 'May clear thinking clean the make-believe parts so they obey it and look like real history.' (fixes pronoun, plain 'obey' for hypakouo). R2: 'But if they won't mix with what makes sense and stubbornly ignore it, we'll ask nice listeners to be kind to the old tales.' (drops 'scorn/blend/believable/likely' for 'mix/ignore/makes sense/nice/kind'; merges for flow). Full: Merge into one para if needed, test read-aloud for 7yo smoothness.

sequential_iterations.translation: May the make-believe parts get cleaned by clear thinking, so they follow it and look like true history. But where they stubbornly scorn what's believable and refuse to blend with what's likely, we'll ask kind listeners to gently accept the old stories.

translation_step.observations: a) Kid-convo restate: 'I hope smart thinking cleans the pretend story parts so they act right and look like real history. But if they won't mix with sensible stuff and say no way, we'll ask nice kids listening to be easy on the old tales.' b) Source-close sketch: 'May-be to-us purifying-with-logos the-mythical submitting-and-taking history's-sight, where-ever but arrogantly the-plausible disdaining and not-receiving the-toward-likely mixing, of-clear-minded listeners needing and mildly the-antiquities receiving.' c) Candidates: 1. 'May reason purge myths to obey and wear history's face; where it scorns plausible and shuns likely blend, beg indulgent hearers for old records.' (syntax-parallel). 2. 'Clean fairy tales with logic till they're history-like. If not, hope readers forgive ancient yarns.' (breaks syntax for punchy modern). 3. 'Use clear heads to fix make-believe into true tales. Stubborn parts that ignore sense? Ask patient friends to like grandpa stories.' (kid-flow, drops conditionals). Prior: Fix prev 'scorn'/'believable' to 'ignore'/'makes sense'; clarify 'obey' for hypakouo; smooth personification to direct action; test 7yo read-aloud flow.
translation_step.translation: May clear thinking clean the make-believe parts so they obey it and look like real history. But if they stubbornly ignore what makes sense and refuse to mix with it, we'll ask kind listeners to gently welcome the old tales.

judgment_step.overall_judgment: Strong readability for a 7-year-old with smooth flow and everyday words, but faithfulness dips from loose personification of 'make-believe parts' and vague pronouns that obscure the source's contrast between myth/reason and myth/probability.
judgment_step.strengths: Uses plain clauses like 'clean the make-believe parts' and 'look like real history' to make abstracts concrete; maintains core wish-contrast structure without dropping relations; natural modern phrasing like 'stubbornly ignore' and 'gently welcome' flows like a kids' storybook.
judgment_step.issues: Personifies 'make-believe parts' as 'they' who 'obey/mix/ignore/refuse,' forcing abstraction where source treats myth as a unified element submitting or scorning; unclear pronouns ('it' jumps from 'clear thinking' to 'what makes sense'); 'clear thinking' still mildly abstract for 7yo vs. plainer 'reason' or 'logic'; 'what makes sense' blurs distinct πιθανοῦ (plausible) and εἰκὸς (likely) into one vague term, softening contrast.
judgment_step.revision_plan: Change to: 'I hope reason cleans the fairy-tale stuff so it obeys and looks like true history. But if it stubbornly scorns believable things and won't blend with what's likely, we'll beg for kind listeners who gently accept the old stories.' This drops forced 'they' plural/personification, clarifies with 'fairy-tale stuff'/'believable things'/'what's likely' for 7yo plainness, uses 'I hope'/'beg' for natural optative/deprecatory verbs, and merges 'old tales' to 'old stories' for dignity without cutesiness.

sequential_iterations.translation: May clear thinking clean the make-believe parts so they obey it and look like real history. But if they stubbornly ignore what makes sense and refuse to mix with it, we'll ask kind listeners to gently welcome the old tales.

final_agent_versions.sequential: May good sense clean the make-believe stories so they obey and look like real history. But wherever they won't mix in anything that makes sense, we'll ask for kind listeners who gently welcome the old tales.

final_synthesis.final_translation: May good sense clean the make-believe stories so they obey and look like real history. But wherever they won't mix in anything that makes sense, we'll ask for kind listeners who gently welcome the old tales.
final_synthesis.justification: Iteration 2 best balances 7yo readability with smooth plain clauses and everyday swaps ('make-believe stories' for myth, 'good sense' for reason/logos, 'makes sense' for plausible/likely, 'real history' for history's look); preserves core wish-contrast, plural 'we', and relations without bookish words like 'scorn/believable'; light refine fixes agency to passive-ish 'good sense clean...obey' for faithfulness to myth submitting, drops minor repetition, keeps one para flow.

final_translation: May good sense clean the make-believe stories so they obey and look like real history. But wherever they won't mix in anything that makes sense, we'll ask for kind listeners who gently welcome the old tales.
